title: 106_s1468
content:
The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a symbol of democracy, with millions of visitors annually lacking proper facilities. Security is provided by the Capitol Police, and funds have been allocated for a Visitor Center to enhance the visitor experience. Coins are authorized to commemorate this initiative. Coins are authorized to commemorate the first convening of Congress in the Capitol building, with proceeds from sales deposited for the Capitol Visitor Center's construction and preservation. Coins are authorized to commemorate the first convening of Congress in the Capitol building, with proceeds from sales deposited for the Capitol Visitor Center's construction and preservation. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue various coins, including bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins. Specifications for each type of coin are outlined, such as weight, diameter, and metal composition. If bimetallic coin minting is not feasible, the Secretary may instead mint $5 gold coins. The Secretary may mint up to 100,000 $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. Mintage levels can be waived, and the coins are legal tender. SEC. 4. The Secretary will obtain platinum, gold, and silver from various sources for minting coins under this Act. SEC. 5. The design of the coins will be determined accordingly. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each combination of denomination and quality. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish a promotional role for the coins, and may enter into a contract for marketing purposes. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges for the coins will be set by the Secretary at specified amounts. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund for aiding in the construction, maintenance, and preservation of a Capitol Visitor Center.
